item.title: Installing Node Exporter on Remote Servers
item.description: create folder for exporter apps sudo mkdir /usr/local/bin/metrics sudo mkdir /etc/metrics sudo useradd -rs /bin/false exporter sudo chmod -R 777 /usr/local/bin/metrics sudo chmod -R 777 /etc/metrics sudo chown -R exporter:exporter /usr/local/bin/metrics sudo chown -R exporter:exporter /etc/metrics Install node_exporter curl -O -L https://github.com/prometheus/node_exporter/releases/download/v1.2.2/node_exporter-1.2.2.linux-amd64.tar.gz tar xzvf node_exporter-*.*-amd64.tar.gz sudo mv node_exporter-*.*-amd64 /usr/local/bin/node_exporter create service sudo vim /etc/systemd/system/node_exporter.service [Unit] Description=Node exporter for Prometheus After=network.target [Service] User=exporter Type=simple ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/node_exporter/node_exporter [Install] WantedBy=multi-user.

item.title: Adding SSL certificate to Apache
item.description: Adapted from the Certbot website Obtain a certificate using Certbot The Certbot app recommends using the ‘snap’ package manager for installation. First we’ll make sure Snapd is installed and updated to handle the Certbot app installation. We then install the app, confirm that the command is correctly ‘linked’ and then we’ll request a certificate. Update snapd sudo snap install core; sudo snap refresh core Install Certbot app sudo snap install --classic certbot Prepare the Certbot command sudo ln -s /snap/bin/certbot /usr/bin/certbot If Apache is currently running, disable it so Certbot can use the port sudo systemctl stop apache2.

item.title: Robocopy Notes
item.description: When moving large files or large amounts of files/folders across the network you should use the robocopy app. It will look something like this: robocopy <Source> <Destination> [<File>[...]] [<Options>] In practice it will look something like this robocopy $NETWORK_PATH $NEW_NETWORK_PATH /e /zb /dcopy:t /copy:all /r:2 /w:5 /v /tee /LOG:$PATH_TO_LOG List Only Flag It’s strongly suggested to do a test run with a robocopy command first to make sure you get the intended results, especially when the command involves moving files across the network.

item.title: Adding logins with Apache
item.description: Following these directions will add a username and password prompt to a website or specific webpage. Typically we use this to hide a ‘Dev’ website so it can still be accessible but not open to the public. Using htpasswd to generate users and passwords Install Dependencies Make sure you have Apache Extended Utilities installed sudo apt update sudo apt install apache2-utils Create first user with htpasswd sudo htpasswd -c /etc/apache2/htpasswd.

item.title: Connecting to the UNR VPN
item.description: UNR has a VPN (Virtual Private Network) which allows for staff to access the university network from home or other ‘remote’ locations. item.title: Updating PHP 7.2 > 7.4 on Ubuntu 18
item.description: I have had problems getting PHP 7.2 to update to 7.4 on Ubuntu 18.04. Here’s what I did to get it working. Manually add PHP repository and check again sudo apt install software-properties-common sudo add-apt-repository ppa:ondrej/php sudo apt update sudo apt upgrade Check PHP version again php -v If PHP still shows 7.2 then 7.4 needs to be manually installed Install PHP 7.4 sudo apt install php7.

item.title: Connecting to the UNR Remote Desktop
item.description: The university has a Remote Desktop server that allows you to work on the University Network from anywhere with an internet connection. item.title: Panopticon
item.description: 08/30/22 Panopticon is the monitoring server that we use to monitor the logs and metrics of our many servers. The site works on a stack of Linux, Apache, Prometheus, Loki, and Grafana. The server is accessible at panopticon.casat.org. In order to collect the metrics, Prometheus utilizes a few ‘exporters’ which are small apps used to either collect information or forward information on to the Prometheus server. On the panopticon server there is the Blackbox Exporter installed to periodically ping our remote servers and collect connectivity statistics.

item.title: Remote Workers
item.description: If you are one of our remote workers you will receive a laptop from us for work use at home. Our typical remote setup includes a laptop, monitor, keyboard and mouse (and dock if necessary), all of which will be sent to you. On a typical setup you would plug the monitor into the laptop which will allow you to use either the monitor or both the monitor and the laptop as screens, and then the mouse and keyboard into the laptop.

item.title: Texting Resources
item.description: At CASAT we utilize two different texting services depending on your need, either TextMagic or EZTexing. New Accounts When making new accounts for either of these services, please keep in mind you should use a CASAT ‘group’ email account. As this allows for greater user control within CASAT and helps us keep up continuity of operations. If you have questions about this please contact either the IT or Media teams and they can assist you prior to making any new accounts with either service.
